panels.description: The Health panel displays the overall health for a given host.
panels.title: Health

panels.description: The Bricks panel displays brick status information for a given host, including the total number of bricks in the host, and a count of bricks by status. For details, go to the Bricks Dashboard.

The Brick Status panel displays the status code of each brick for a given host.  
0 = Started  
8 = Stopped
panels.title: Brick Status

panels.description: Memory Available is the sum of memory free and memory cached
panels.title: Memory Available

panels.description:
The Memory Utilization panel displays memory utilization percentage for a given host that includes buffers and caches used by the kernel over a period of time. 
 
Buffered:  Amount of memory used for buffering, mostly for I/O operations.  
Cached:  Memory used for caching disk data for reads, memory-mapped files or tmpfs data.  
Slab Rec:  Amount of reclaimable memory used for slab kernel allocations.  
Slab Unrecl:  Amount of unreclaimable memory used for slab kernel allocations.  
Used:  Amount of memory used, calculated as Total - Free (Unused Memory) - Buffered - Cache  

The memory utilization threshold is set to 80%. Reaching or exceeding this value displays an orange horizontal line indicating high memory usage.
panels.title: Memory Utilization

panels.description: The Swap Free panel displays the available swap space in percent for a given host.
panels.title: Swap Free

panels.description: The Swap Utilization panel displays the used swap space in percent for a given host.
panels.title: Swap Utilization

panels.description: The CPU utilization panel displays the CPU utilization for a given host over a period of time.
panels.title: CPU Utilization

panels.description: The Brick IOPS panel displays aggregated brick level read and write operations collected using “gluster volume profile info” over a period of time. The IOPS value is aggregated from bricks which are part of volumes that have volume profiling enabled. No data will be shown unless at least one brick is part of a volume that has volume profiling enabled.
panels.title: Brick IOPS

panels.description: The Total Brick Capacity Utilization panel displays the capacity utilization for all bricks on a given for a period of time.
panels.title: Total Brick Capacity Utilization

panels.description: The Total Brick Capacity Utilization panel displays the current percent capacity utilization for a given host.
panels.title: Total Brick Capacity Utilization

panels.description: The Total Brick Capacity Available panel displays the current available capacity for a given host.
panels.title: Total Brick Capacity Available

panels.description: The Weekly Growth Rate panel displays the forecasted weekly growth rate for capacity utilization computed based on daily capacity utilization.
panels.title: Weekly Growth Rate

panels.description: The Weeks Remaining panel displays the estimated time remaining in weeks till host capacity reaches full capacity based on the forecasted Weekly Growth Rate.
panels.title: Weeks Remaining
Top Bricks by Capacity Percent Utilized

panels.description: The Disk Throughput panel shows the host’s aggregated read and writes from/to disks over a period of time.
panels.title: Disk Throughput

panels.description: The Disk IOPS panel shows the host’s aggregated read and writes disk IOPS over a period of time.
panels.title: Disk IOPS

panels.description: The Disk IO Latency panel shows the host’s aggregated I/O time over a period of time.
panels.title: Disk IO Latency

panels.description: The Throughput panel displays the network throughput for a given host over a period of time.
panels.title: Throughput

panels.description: The Dropped Packets Per Second panel displays dropped network packets for the host over a period of time.  Typically, dropped packets indicates network congestion, e.g. the queue on the switch port your host is connected to is full and packets are dropped because it can’t transmit data fast enough.
panels.title: Dropped Packets Per Second

panels.description: The Errors Per Second panel displays network errors for a given host over a period of time.  Typically, the errors indicate issues that occurred while transmitting packets due to carrier errors (duplex mismatch, faulty cable), fifo errors, heartbeat errors, and window errors, CRC errors too short frames, and/or too long frames. In short, errors typically result from faulty hardware, and/or speed mismatch.
panels.title: Errors Per Second
